findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: The transactions are initially disabled for all users excluding the authorized addresses. The owner can enable the transactions for all users. Once the transactions are enabled the owner will not be able to disable them again.

findings.title: IVU - Inefficient Variable Usage
findings.description: The contract uses two separate variables, `maxTxAmount` and `maxWalletBalance`, to control transaction limits, but both are set to the same value, making one of the conditions redundant. This redundancy adds unnecessary complexity to the contract and consumes additional gas.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards. The `immutable` declaration can save gas by making certain optimizations.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: RFO - Redundant Function Override
findings.description: The contract employs a custom `renounceOwnership` function, which is defined as a public function overriding the base implementation. This function delegates the inherited `super.renounceOwnership()` method. The custom implementation in this contract does not modify or extend the functionality of the inherited method.

findings.title: RID - Redundant Interface Declaration
findings.description: The contract includes an interface declaration that does not contain any code. While this does not affect the contract's security or functionality, it can increase complexity and make it harder to comprehend, which may result in maintenance difficulties and security risks.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of variables without checking if their current value is the same as the one given as an argument, leading to redundant storage writes and unnecessary gas consumption.

findings.title: RC - Repetitive Calculations
findings.description: The contract contains segments with multiple occurrences of the same calculation being performed without utilizing a variable to store its result, leading to redundant code, hindering code readability, and increasing gas consumption.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L18 - Multiple Pragma Directives
findings.description: If the contract includes multiple conflicting pragma directives, it may produce unexpected errors.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
